I support this feature. Our use case:
There are 50 or so of us in a Signal group who review opportunities (often a 1-2 page document). We then create a new signal group for each opportunity that is of interest to 2 or more folks to move the opportunity specific discussion to that single topic group. Since there are 50 in the original group, folks get added at various times and when they do, they have no access to all the discussion (and documents for that matter) that came before they joined the topic specific group.

posts.name: Peter Eckersley
posts.cooked:
(This is a protocol feature request, but can’t see a Discourse tag for those).

Group conversations have different use cases that map to different ideal behaviour wrt conversation history. If a group is for fast-moving, informal or social coordination between participants, it’s reasonable design that newly added members cannot see conversation history from the period before they joined the group.

On the other hand, if a group conversation is being used to coordinate work between a growing group of humans, it may be quite valuable for newly joining participants to be able to look and search back through the history to understand context, look up resources, and read bios and introductions where people have made those.

It therefore seems as though Signal could be much more useful for the second kind of use case if groups had an option to enable permanently persistent history, which is shared to new clients when they join the group for the first time.

My quick read of post on the current group chat design suggests that this shouldn’t be too algorithmically difficult to implement. Thoughts either way?

posts.cooked:
Doubt this would be considered or introduced.
Also not something I’d advocate for, Signal is designed with privacy at its heart, as a private messenger, not really a productivity/office replacement tool.

If I am in a group chat, I’m sending my message knowing it’s going to X number of people within that group and am comfortable that message is being read by only those individuals. I don’t like the idea that someone else (who is not me) can decide to extend these messages to a wider audience than I originally agreed to when I sent the message. ie the group admin later invites 50 other people and my historic messages are suddenly available to all those people without my consent. - doesn’t sound very private.

The fact Signal doesn’t share prior chat history between your own linked devices, means it’s extremely unlikely for prior chat history with even more participants, if they don’t even do it for your own.

Putting that aside it would also be a technical challenge, as Signal is not storing the history of group messages server-side after they have been delivered to all parties.

posts.name: Peter Eckersley
posts.cooked:
Josh I agree for privacy reasons this feature should not be the default, but none of your points are relevant to or address whether such a feature should be an option. As for implementation, I don’t think it’s that hard – if the client of the user or admin who adds someone has a local copy of the history of messages, that client can just send the history once a new member has joined.

(Signal also badly needs to implement optional multi-client history syncing, the lack o fwhich causes many of my contacts to get frustrated and uninstall Signal, but that’s a topic for a different thread on a different day ;)

@pde.is I think the point I’m making has been lost on you.

My point is that considering the Signal teams philosophy is privacy is number 1 priority above all. I don’t see them ever introducing this. I also see it being a complete nightmare from a user experience point of view.

Your view is clearly at the start of joining a group chat you’re told “this chat shares all previous history with new group members”.
Which means if I’m a member of this group, I have no control if my message is later shared with someone I don’t want to see it. Say I write “John is not very good at his job”, then 2 weeks later a group member invites John. I sent my message knowing John was NOT a member of this group.

So that’s my issue, someone else is sharing my message with someone I did not consent to see the message. The argument “but you’re joining a group with chat history sent to new members” is not lost on me, I just believe the benefits it provides removes the privacy and consent benefits.

The other alternative is that every time a new member is added, everyone in the group has to provide consent. That would just be a poor user experience as you’d have to review all the chat history, then everyone agree to allow them to see the history.

You also suggested addressing the technical element, that a group admin etc who has a local chat history would then be uploaded from their device for the new member. What if that prior chat has lots of photos and videos, could be a very large upload and download each time a new member is added, to make this feature possible. Otherwise the full chat history has to remain server-side forever. Neither option I’d be advocating for.

My commentary was this tool is for private chats, not a work productivity tool, so privacy is the main factor for using this tool. Hence I have a strong view on keeping my chats private.

There are many existing productivity tools that do exactly what you are wanting, Signal should not be a catch all. It should be at its heart a private, secure, personal messenger, which is why new members do not need to see prior chat history as they were never part of that chat at that point in time.

Teams, Slack, ect ect etc offer a team productivity tool.

joshobrien:

The other alternative is that every time a new member is added, everyone in the group has to provide consent. That would just be a poor user experience as you’d have to review all the chat history, then everyone agree to allow them to see the history.

I want to add, that there may be a huge peer pressure that everyone should agree otherwise you are the one which decided on the joining person not to read the chat history.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
PiCob:

That being said: since every reipient could have deleted random messages locally, you can’t expect a “full copy” even exists client-side in first place.

Moreover, the local messages that weren’t deleted can’t really be trusted either. Signal provides deniable authentication, which, as far as I know, means that after a message is decrypted (and then stored locally) you can’t cryptographically prove to some new member that it really was sent by who you think it was. This means that a user could modify the message history locally (e.g. with a custom client or if Practical Deniability: local message editing is implemented) and then the new member would receive a fake history.

posts.name: Peter Eckersley
posts.cooked:
@jeremymasters, alas, if you are collaborating with a group of people and the Admin / person who gathered you adds malicious people to the group, you are unfortunately sunk – the malicious person is on your team going forward, not just reading messages but gaining the trust of your team members too.

It’s important to have technology that aligns with real-world threat models, and one of the main ones is “this is a group of people who trust each other, or trust the admins to exercise judgement about the membership of the group, and once people are in the group they need the best tools to collaborate as efficiently as possible on their shared project(s), with shared privacy as a group”.

@everyone Do other folks in this thread not think/agree that this is a reasonable threat model for some real world groups acting together to adopt? Or do you just think that such groups should not use Signal (if so, what should they use instead?)
